contentrichtext.text: {{nihongo|'''Tōyō'''|東陽村|Tōyō-son}} was a [[villages of Japan|village]] located in [[Yatsushiro District, Kumamoto|Yatsuhiro District]], [[Kumamoto Prefecture|Kumamoto]], [[Japan]]. On August 1, 2005 Tōyō, along with the towns of [[Kagami, Kumamoto|Kagami]] and [[Senchō, Kumamoto|Senchō]], and the villages of [[Izumi, Kumamoto|Izumi]] and [[Sakamoto, Kumamoto|Sakamoto]], all from [[Yatsushiro District, Kumamoto|Yatsushiro District]], was merged into the expanded city of [[Yatsushiro, Kumamoto|Yatsushiro]] and no longer exists as an independent [[municipalities of Japan|municipality]]. Tōyō is now officially referred to as ''Tōyō-machi'' (東陽町), or ''Tōyō town''. As of 2003, the village had an estimated [[population]] of 2,787 and a [[population density]] of 43.17 persons per km². The total area was 64.56 km². Tōyō is famous for its ginger, and every October the town holds its annual ''shōgamatsuri'', or ginger festival. The town is also known for its old stone bridges, or ''ishibashi'', of which many were built during the [[Meiji period]]. In addition, the town has one [[onsen]] named ''Seseragi''. ==External links== * [http://www.city.yatsushiro.kumamoto.jp/ Official website of Yatsushiro] {{ja icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Toyo, Kumamoto}} [[Category:Dissolved municipalities of Kumamoto Prefecture]] {{Kumamoto-geo-stub}}
